Constellations is ten songs long and incorporates influences from pop, folk, electronic, rock and classical music Ã¢â‚¬â€œ to name a few. Their sound is theatrical, mystical and highly immersive.

True to the album-titleÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s starry connotations, the opening-tracks Ã¢â‚¬ËœGlorious YearÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ and Ã¢â‚¬ËœConstellationsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ are poppy, outlandish, and accompanied by plenty of twinkling. However, part of what makes the album so entrancing is its unpredictability. After the optimistic and catchy opening, the tone changes dramatically and spirals down into a very different, darker place. Here, mechanical and dramatic songs like Ã¢â‚¬ËœLady VengeanceÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ and Ã¢â‚¬ËœKeep It As A MemoryÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ echo the notes of an apocalypse.

The ominous tone lingers, but the journey swiftly moves on to new places where tracks like Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe Night Is YoungÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ and Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe Land Of The Midnight SunÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ await. The former is a carnival-esque waltz, and the latter a fable-like hymn consisting of angelic harmonies and a harp. On occasion, the collision of styles results in a lack of direction, but this is a minor problem. Most songs stand strong on their own, and the dark undertones remain as a constant thread tying them together.

While Hannah Miller leads, they all sing, and between the five band-members they play twelve instruments, so with guests like Arthur Brown and The Unthanks taking part, grand and elaborate arrangements are to be expected.
